docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''What Tax Cuts Can Buy for Health,'' by Matthew Miller (Op-Ed, Dec. 28):

headline.main: Mixing Tax Cuts With Health Care

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Gerald Gollin says tax credits for purchase of private health insurance, suggeested in Matthew Miller's Dec 28 Op-Ed article, are form of indirect corporate welfare that would likely not achieve anything near universal coverage
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''What Tax Cuts Can Buy for Health,'' by Matthew Miller (Op-Ed, Dec. 28):

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Bill Clinton moved into the White House eight years ago, the economy was starting to gather strength but the federal budget deficit was getting bigger, leaving the new president handcuffed when it came to fiscal policy. His successor will inherit a very different situation. George W. Bush will become president at a time when the economy is weakening but the budget surplus seems to swell with each new calculation and deficits are but a dim memory.

headline.main: Bush's Task: Deciding How He'll Spend A Big Surplus

docs.abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column on surplus that will give Pres-elect George W Bush more flexibility in setting budget than any president in generation; notes he must decide whether to use fiscal policy to try to manage ups and downs of business cycle, how serious to be about paying off national debt and whether to push hard for plan to cut all income tax rates in way that would give most of cut in dollar terms to high-income people; budget graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TO help pay medical bills left behind when her husband, Gordon, died of skin cancer complications last summer, June Yeager, 82, of Oakdale, Minn., was forced to use a third of his $10,000 in life insurance. It was not that the Yeagers lacked health insurance; they were eligible for Medicare and received benefits from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, from which Mr. Yeager retired in 1975 as a shipping clerk. But 3M decided in 1994 to alter its benefits package for retirees: Retired employees said it increased the annual out-of-pocket deductions for retired blue-collar union members, for example, to $1,500 from $140, and cut back on payments for doctor bills not covered under Medicare.

headline.main: Cuts in Health Benefits Squeeze Retirees' Nest Eggs

docs.abstract: Most employers have cut or dropped health coverage for retirees in last six or seven years as health care costs have soared, forcing retirees to pick up more costs; fewer than 25 percent of employers with 500 or more workers now provide medical coverage of any kind for Medicare-eligible retirees, down from 40 percent in 1994; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Exactly one year from this morning, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will wake up to his last day of ruling a city that he has inspired and infuriated for two operatic terms. The crescendo came of course in 2000, the year that brought the public collapse of the mayor's marriage, his withdrawal from a Senate race against a famous first lady and his fight against prostate cancer, the disease that killed his father. Last week, on the eve of his eighth and last year in a job that he has often said is the best he'll ever have, Mr. Giuliani ruminated on the 365 days that term limits have left him. ''I think it's a year that's been given to me that I wouldn't have had, had I gone in a different direction,'' the mayor said in reflective, hourlong remarks to reporters as he sat framed by an imposing portrait of James Monroe at City Hall.

headline.main: The Rest Of the Way; Giuliani Sets Priorities That Will Determine His Legacy as Mayor

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani discusses his plans for his final year in office; sets series of priorities that will determine his legacy as mayor, including policies on housing, racial minorities, new stadium, education and health insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A FAMILIAR face missing from the cafeteria line, a vacant chair at the board meeting, an empty spot on the bench at the corner park -- these are the kinds of holes that death tears in a community. Memories remain alive, of course, for families, friends and colleagues.
docs.abstract: Profiles of people whose deaths in year 2000 diminished New Jersey but whose achievements and examples continue to enhance their communities; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's poor are eligible for some of the most generous health benefits in the country, but the annual process required to renew them inadvertently leaves thousands uninsured for months or longer, say insurance executives, policy experts and state legislators. As many as half of the roughly two million children enrolled in public insurance programs end up uncovered for some period because their parents do not follow through with the required process to renew their benefits, several studies show.

headline.main: For Poor, Health Benefits Are Easier to Have Than to Hold

docs.abstract: Insurance executives, policy experts and New York State legislators say that state's poor are eligible for some of most generous health benefits in country but annual process required to renew them inadvertently leaves thousands uninsured for months or longer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: James Castle, a Medicare recipient and retired factory worker with a bad heart, has been in three health maintenance organizations in the past three years. His present one is dropping him as of Jan. 1. The first, United Healthcare of Ohio, cut benefits, so he switched. The second, Secure Horizons, left the state. His current one, Aetna U.S. Healthcare, will drop all 52,330 Medicare H.M.O. beneficiaries in Ohio on Jan. 1, having concluded that ''inadequate government reimbursements have made operating a number of our Medicare H.M.O.'s no longer viable.''

headline.main: H.M.O.'s to Drop Many Elderly and Disabled People

docs.abstract: Across nation, 933,687 elderly and disabled people will be dropped on first day of 2001 by HMO's pulling out of Medicare program; recent survey finds dropped Medicare recipients are likely to be poorer, less educated and in worse health than others in program; health experts say most severe consequence for elderly and disabled being dropped by their HMO's is loss of prescription drug benefits that cover 68 percent of those enrolled in such plans; basic fee-for-service Medicare does not pay for drugs, nor do supplemental Medicare policies, so-called Medigap plans; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ASIA INDONESIA: SUHARTO SON FOUND, AND GONE -- President Abdurrahman Wahid said security forces had found the fugitive son of former President Suharto, who has been evading an arrest on corruption charges for two months. But he said the son, known as Tommy, left, had slipped away while officers were checking with the palace on whether to arrest him. ''When the timing is right, he will be detained,'' Mr. Wahid said. Seth Mydans (NYT)
